levelledPara.title: Wing Structure System Overview
levelledPara.para: The BWB-Q100 wing structure represents an advanced blended wing body configuration designed for hydrogen-powered commercial aviation. The wing integrates primary structural elements with cryogenic liquid hydrogen (LH₂) fuel storage systems, providing both structural continuity and fuel containment within a unified aerodynamic envelope. The wing structure encompasses ATA-57 scope covering wing box primary structure (57-10-10), wing skins/stringers/spars/ribs (57-10-20), wing/fuselage integration (57-10-30), and equipment attachment fittings (57-10-40), with specific provisions for hydrogen fuel system interfaces.

levelledPara.title: Wing Box Structure (57-10-10)
levelledPara.para: The primary wing box consists of a multi-spar, multi-rib configuration optimized for blended wing body load distribution. The structure incorporates front spar (Station FS-100) as primary structural element carrying wing bending loads and hydrogen tank forward attachment points, main spar (Station FS-200) as central load-bearing member integrating with centerbody structure, rear spar (Station FS-300) as aft structural element supporting control surfaces and fuel system venting, and auxiliary spar (Station FS-250) as intermediate support for hydrogen tank mounting and access panels.

listItem.para: Carbon fiber reinforced plastic (CFRP) panels with [±45°/0°/90°] layup optimized for in-plane loads
Integral stringers at 150mm spacing providing local buckling resistance and damage tolerance
Thermal barriers and insulation interfaces for cryogenic hydrogen containment
Access panel cutouts for hydrogen system maintenance with reinforcing doublers
Primary ribs at stations WS-50, WS-150, WS-250, WS-350, WS-450 with full-depth construction
Intermediate ribs at 500mm spacing providing local load distribution
Hydrogen tank support ribs with cryogenic thermal isolation mounting systems
Fuel line routing channels and vibration isolation provisions

levelledPara.title: Hydrogen Fuel System Integration Overview
levelledPara.para: The wing structure incorporates comprehensive provisions for cryogenic liquid hydrogen storage and distribution, representing a critical interface between ATA-57 (Wings) and ATA-28 (Fuel System). The hydrogen integration encompasses safety, structural, and operational considerations for zero-emission aviation operations.

listItem.para: Type IV pressure vessels (carbon fiber overwrapped) rated for 350 bar operating pressure
Tank capacities: 2 × 1,500 kg LH₂ per wing (total 6,000 kg system capacity)
Cryogenic insulation system: Multi-layer insulation (MLI) with vacuum barrier
Thermal isolation mounts using low-conductivity titanium alloy Ti-6Al-4V fittings
Tank mounting at four cardinal points with thermal expansion accommodation
Primary relief valves: 2 per tank, sized for 110% of maximum fill rate
Emergency vent lines routed through rear spar to wing tip discharge points
Thermally activated pressure relief devices (TPRD) for fire exposure scenarios
Vent system isolation from ignition sources with 10-meter exclusion zones
Fire barriers: Inconel 625 sheets with ceramic fiber insulation
Hydrogen detection system integration in wing voids
Emergency electrical isolation provisions for hydrogen zones
Cross-reference to ATA-47 (Inert Gas) for nitrogen purging systems

levelledPara.title: Load Transfer Paths and Structural Continuity
levelledPara.para: The BWB-Q100 wing structure provides continuous load paths from centerbody through wing box to wing tips, accommodating both aerodynamic and hydrogen system loads. Primary load paths include: Centerbody → Wing box front spar → Wing spars → Wing tip structure; Wing box upper/lower covers → Spar webs → Rib structures → Skin panels; Hydrogen tank loads → Thermal isolation mounts → Primary ribs → Spar attachments; Landing gear loads (wing-mounted MLG) → Gear beam → Wing box → Centerbody.
